Upskill in AI tools, chase internships, and think beyond code to domain expertise. The old IT ladder is broken, but the highway to new-age roles is wide open. âœ¨ Exciting News! âœ¨Iâ€™m thrilled to share that I am officially a first-time author! Our paper, â€œBeyond the Job Posting: What Hiring Managers Seek in Entry-Level Software Engineering Candidatesâ€, co-authored with Bianca Trinkenreich, Ph.D. and Fabio Santos, PhD, has been accepted to the ESEM Conference (Empirical Software Engineering and Measurement)!Our research focused on two main questions: 1ï¸âƒ£ What do hiring managers expect from entry-level software engineering candidates? 2ï¸âƒ£ How are these expectations reflected in job postings?Here are some key insights: âœ… Hiring managers prioritize non-technical skills such as Adaptability, Proactivity, Dependability, Self-Direction, Passion, Collaboration, Communication, Problem Solving, Courage, Self-Awareness, Self-Confidence, Willingness to Learn, and a Process-Oriented Mindset. âœ… Most of these skills are not explicitly stated in job postings.This means many graduates may feel deterred by technical requirements in postingsâ€”yet hiring managers care deeply about these essential non-technical skills that help candidates grow their technical toolkit over time.A huge thank you to everyone who contributed to our data collection. Your support made this research possible!ğŸ’¬ Iâ€™d love to hear your thoughts: What non-technical skills do you think are most important for entry-level engineers?hashtag#ESEM hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#Hiring hashtag#CareerDevelopment hashtag#Research

âœ¨ Exciting News! âœ¨Iâ€™m thrilled to share that I am officially a first-time author! Our paper, â€œBeyond the Job Posting: What Hiring Managers Seek in Entry-Level Software Engineering Candidatesâ€, co-authored with Bianca Trinkenreich, Ph.D. and Fabio Santos, PhD, has been accepted to the ESEM Conference (Empirical Software Engineering and Measurement)!Our research focused on two main questions: 1ï¸âƒ£ What do hiring managers expect from entry-level software engineering candidates? 2ï¸âƒ£ How are these expectations reflected in job postings?Here are some key insights: âœ… Hiring managers prioritize non-technical skills such as Adaptability, Proactivity, Dependability, Self-Direction, Passion, Collaboration, Communication, Problem Solving, Courage, Self-Awareness, Self-Confidence, Willingness to Learn, and a Process-Oriented Mindset. âœ… Most of these skills are not explicitly stated in job postings.This means many graduates may feel deterred by technical requirements in postingsâ€”yet hiring managers care deeply about these essential non-technical skills that help candidates grow their technical toolkit over time.A huge thank you to everyone who contributed to our data collection. Your support made this research possible!ğŸ’¬ Iâ€™d love to hear your thoughts: What non-technical skills do you think are most important for entry-level engineers?hashtag#ESEM hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#Hiring hashtag#CareerDevelopment hashtag#Research

Our education system is stuck in 2015, with only 12% of Indian engineering colleges teaching AI or data science. Meanwhile, Global Capability Centres (GCCs) are hiringâ€”but they want thinkers, not coders, from top-tier institutes. Yet, thereâ€™s hope. AI is birthing roles like prompt engineers and model auditors, accessible to those who adapt fast. This isnâ€™t the endâ€”itâ€™s a pivot point. AI isnâ€™t the enemy; itâ€™s your co-pilot. Upskill in AI tools, chase internships, and think beyond code to domain expertise. The old IT ladder is broken, but the highway to new-age roles is wide open. âœ¨ Exciting News! âœ¨Iâ€™m thrilled to share that I am officially a first-time author! Our paper, â€œBeyond the Job Posting: What Hiring Managers Seek in Entry-Level Software Engineering Candidatesâ€, co-authored with Bianca Trinkenreich, Ph.D. and Fabio Santos, PhD, has been accepted to the ESEM Conference (Empirical Software Engineering and Measurement)!Our research focused on two main questions: 1ï¸âƒ£ What do hiring managers expect from entry-level software engineering candidates? 2ï¸âƒ£ How are these expectations reflected in job postings?Here are some key insights: âœ… Hiring managers prioritize non-technical skills such as Adaptability, Proactivity, Dependability, Self-Direction, Passion, Collaboration, Communication, Problem Solving, Courage, Self-Awareness, Self-Confidence, Willingness to Learn, and a Process-Oriented Mindset. âœ… Most of these skills are not explicitly stated in job postings.This means many graduates may feel deterred by technical requirements in postingsâ€”yet hiring managers care deeply about these essential non-technical skills that help candidates grow their technical toolkit over time.A huge thank you to everyone who contributed to our data collection. Your support made this research possible!ğŸ’¬ Iâ€™d love to hear your thoughts: What non-technical skills do you think are most important for entry-level engineers?hashtag#ESEM hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#Hiring hashtag#CareerDevelopment hashtag#Research

âœ¨ Exciting News! âœ¨Iâ€™m thrilled to share that I am officially a first-time author! Our paper, â€œBeyond the Job Posting: What Hiring Managers Seek in Entry-Level Software Engineering Candidatesâ€, co-authored with Bianca Trinkenreich, Ph.D. and Fabio Santos, PhD, has been accepted to the ESEM Conference (Empirical Software Engineering and Measurement)!Our research focused on two main questions: 1ï¸âƒ£ What do hiring managers expect from entry-level software engineering candidates? 2ï¸âƒ£ How are these expectations reflected in job postings?Here are some key insights: âœ… Hiring managers prioritize non-technical skills such as Adaptability, Proactivity, Dependability, Self-Direction, Passion, Collaboration, Communication, Problem Solving, Courage, Self-Awareness, Self-Confidence, Willingness to Learn, and a Process-Oriented Mindset. âœ… Most of these skills are not explicitly stated in job postings.This means many graduates may feel deterred by technical requirements in postingsâ€”yet hiring managers care deeply about these essential non-technical skills that help candidates grow their technical toolkit over time.A huge thank you to everyone who contributed to our data collection. Your support made this research possible!ğŸ’¬ Iâ€™d love to hear your thoughts: What non-technical skills do you think are most important for entry-level engineers?hashtag#ESEM hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#Hiring hashtag#CareerDevelopment hashtag#Research

âœ¨ Exciting News! âœ¨Iâ€™m thrilled to share that I am officially a first-time author! Our paper, â€œBeyond the Job Posting: What Hiring Managers Seek in Entry-Level Software Engineering Candidatesâ€, co-authored with Bianca Trinkenreich, Ph.D. and Fabio Santos, PhD, has been accepted to the ESEM Conference (Empirical Software Engineering and Measurement)!Our research focused on two main questions: 1ï¸âƒ£ What do hiring managers expect from entry-level software engineering candidates? 2ï¸âƒ£ How are these expectations reflected in job postings?Here are some key insights: âœ… Hiring managers prioritize non-technical skills such as Adaptability, Proactivity, Dependability, Self-Direction, Passion, Collaboration, Communication, Problem Solving, Courage, Self-Awareness, Self-Confidence, Willingness to Learn, and a Process-Oriented Mindset. âœ… Most of these skills are not explicitly stated in job postings.This means many graduates may feel deterred by technical requirements in postingsâ€”yet hiring managers care deeply about these essential non-technical skills that help candidates grow their technical toolkit over time.A huge thank you to everyone who contributed to our data collection. Your support made this research possible!ğŸ’¬ Iâ€™d love to hear your thoughts: What non-technical skills do you think are most important for entry-level engineers?hashtag#ESEM hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#Hiring hashtag#CareerDevelopment hashtag#Research

Our education system is stuck in 2015, with only 12% of Indian engineering colleges teaching AI or data science. Meanwhile, Global Capability Centres (GCCs) are hiringâ€”but they want thinkers, not coders, from top-tier institutes. Yet, thereâ€™s hope. AI is birthing roles like prompt engineers and model auditors, accessible to those who adapt fast. This isnâ€™t the endâ€”itâ€™s a pivot point. AI isnâ€™t the enemy; itâ€™s your co-pilot. Upskill in AI tools, chase internships, and think beyond code to domain expertise. The old IT ladder is broken, but the highway to new-age roles is wide open. âœ¨ Exciting News! âœ¨Iâ€™m thrilled to share that I am officially a first-time author! Our paper, â€œBeyond the Job Posting: What Hiring Managers Seek in Entry-Level Software Engineering Candidatesâ€, co-authored with Bianca Trinkenreich, Ph.D. and Fabio Santos, PhD, has been accepted to the ESEM Conference (Empirical Software Engineering and Measurement)!Our research focused on two main questions: 1ï¸âƒ£ What do hiring managers expect from entry-level software engineering candidates? 2ï¸âƒ£ How are these expectations reflected in job postings?Here are some key insights: âœ… Hiring managers prioritize non-technical skills such as Adaptability, Proactivity, Dependability, Self-Direction, Passion, Collaboration, Communication, Problem Solving, Courage, Self-Awareness, Self-Confidence, Willingness to Learn, and a Process-Oriented Mindset. âœ… Most of these skills are not explicitly stated in job postings.This means many graduates may feel deterred by technical requirements in postingsâ€”yet hiring managers care deeply about these essential non-technical skills that help candidates grow their technical toolkit over time.A huge thank you to everyone who contributed to our data collection. Your support made this research possible!ğŸ’¬ Iâ€™d love to hear your thoughts: What non-technical skills do you think are most important for entry-level engineers?hashtag#ESEM hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#Hiring hashtag#CareerDevelopment hashtag#Research

Cracking the Data Engineering Interview: My Complete Guide â¬‡ï¸Day by day, demand for Data Engineers is increasing, but many people are still complaining, "Companies are not hiring for the DE role."It's not a hiring issue, but finding skilled employees is very difficult these daysHereâ€™s a roadmap that I believe every aspiring data engineer should follow to confidently crack interviews at top companies â¬‡ï¸I have also shared the complete bootcamp link in the commentğŸ“˜ Step 1: Master the FundamentalsYou need to go beyond tutorials and build a deep understanding in:ğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Python ğŸ: Data structures, functions, file handling, APIsğŸ‘‰ğŸ» SQL: Joins, Window Functions, CTEs, performance tuningğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Data Modeling: Star vs Snowflake schema, OLTP vs OLAP, Slowly Changing DimensionsğŸ“š Pro Tip: Practice with real business scenarios. Don't just SELECT * FROM knowledge.âš™ï¸ Step 2: Tools of the TradeYouâ€™ll be expected to work with:ğŸ‘‰ğŸ» ETL Tools: Airflow, dbt, GlueğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Data Lakes & Warehouses: Snowflake, BigQuery, Redshift, S3ğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Big Data Processing: Apache Spark, Kafka, HadoopCloud Platforms: AWS/GCP/Azure basics (IAM, EC2, S3, etc.)ğŸ’¡ Interviewers love to ask: â€œHow would you build a pipeline if X data came in late or failed?â€ğŸ§  Step 3: Think Like an EngineerMost candidates fail not because they canâ€™t code, but because they canâ€™t design and debug pipelines.Prepare to answer:â€œHow would you design a pipeline to ingest millions of rows daily?â€â€œHow do you ensure data quality and integrity?â€â€œWhat happens if schema changes mid-stream?â€Draw diagrams. Break down the problem. AI is birthing roles like prompt engineers and model auditors, accessible to those who adapt fast. This isnâ€™t the endâ€”itâ€™s a pivot point. AI isnâ€™t the enemy; itâ€™s your co-pilot. Our paper, â€œBeyond the Job Posting: What Hiring Managers Seek in Entry-Level Software Engineering Candidatesâ€, co-authored with Bianca Trinkenreich, Ph.D. and Fabio Santos, PhD, has been accepted to the ESEM Conference (Empirical Software Engineering and Measurement)!Our research focused on two main questions: 1ï¸âƒ£ What do hiring managers expect from entry-level software engineering candidates? 2ï¸âƒ£ How are these expectations reflected in job postings?Here are some key insights: âœ… Hiring managers prioritize non-technical skills such as Adaptability, Proactivity, Dependability, Self-Direction, Passion, Collaboration, Communication, Problem Solving, Courage, Self-Awareness, Self-Confidence, Willingness to Learn, and a Process-Oriented Mindset. âœ… Most of these skills are not explicitly stated in job postings.This means many graduates may feel deterred by technical requirements in postingsâ€”yet hiring managers care deeply about these essential non-technical skills that help candidates grow their technical toolkit over time.A huge thank you to everyone who contributed to our data collection. Your support made this research possible!ğŸ’¬ Iâ€™d love to hear your thoughts: What non-technical skills do you think are most important for entry-level engineers?hashtag#ESEM hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#Hiring hashtag#CareerDevelopment hashtag#Research

Cracking the Data Engineering Interview: My Complete Guide â¬‡ï¸Day by day, demand for Data Engineers is increasing, but many people are still complaining, "Companies are not hiring for the DE role."It's not a hiring issue, but finding skilled employees is very difficult these daysHereâ€™s a roadmap that I believe every aspiring data engineer should follow to confidently crack interviews at top companies â¬‡ï¸I have also shared the complete bootcamp link in the commentğŸ“˜ Step 1: Master the FundamentalsYou need to go beyond tutorials and build a deep understanding in:ğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Python ğŸ: Data structures, functions, file handling, APIsğŸ‘‰ğŸ» SQL: Joins, Window Functions, CTEs, performance tuningğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Data Modeling: Star vs Snowflake schema, OLTP vs OLAP, Slowly Changing DimensionsğŸ“š Pro Tip: Practice with real business scenarios. Don't just SELECT * FROM knowledge.âš™ï¸ Step 2: Tools of the TradeYouâ€™ll be expected to work with:ğŸ‘‰ğŸ» ETL Tools: Airflow, dbt, GlueğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Data Lakes & Warehouses: Snowflake, BigQuery, Redshift, S3ğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Big Data Processing: Apache Spark, Kafka, HadoopCloud Platforms: AWS/GCP/Azure basics (IAM, EC2, S3, etc.)ğŸ’¡ Interviewers love to ask: â€œHow would you build a pipeline if X data came in late or failed?â€ğŸ§  Step 3: Think Like an EngineerMost candidates fail not because they canâ€™t code, but because they canâ€™t design and debug pipelines.Prepare to answer:â€œHow would you design a pipeline to ingest millions of rows daily?â€â€œHow do you ensure data quality and integrity?â€â€œWhat happens if schema changes mid-stream?â€Draw diagrams. Break down the problem. Think out loud.ğŸ“Š Step 4: Projects > CertificatesReal-world projects >>> random certs.âœ… Build an end-to-end pipeline:- Ingest data from an API- Transform it using Spark/dbt- Store it in a warehouse- Visualize it with Looker or Power BIThis shows not only your skills but also your ability to ship production-ready data systems.ğŸ” Step 5: Mock Interviews & Feedback LoopsDon't prepare in isolation.ğŸ“ˆ Do peer mock interviewsğŸ› ï¸ Use platforms like DataVidhya Code+ to practice PySpark, SQL, Python, DBT, and build Data ModelsğŸ’¬ Ask for resume and project feedback from industry professionals.What if I tell you, everything I mentioned above, you can get it at just one placeâŒ No more jumping from resource to resource, learn everything in one place!Interested? AI is birthing roles like prompt engineers and model auditors, accessible to those who adapt fast. This isnâ€™t the endâ€”itâ€™s a pivot point. AI isnâ€™t the enemy; itâ€™s your co-pilot. Upskill in AI tools, chase internships, and think beyond code to domain expertise. The old IT ladder is broken, but the highway to new-age roles is wide open. âœ¨ Exciting News! âœ¨Iâ€™m thrilled to share that I am officially a first-time author! Our paper, â€œBeyond the Job Posting: What Hiring Managers Seek in Entry-Level Software Engineering Candidatesâ€, co-authored with Bianca Trinkenreich, Ph.D. and Fabio Santos, PhD, has been accepted to the ESEM Conference (Empirical Software Engineering and Measurement)!Our research focused on two main questions: 1ï¸âƒ£ What do hiring managers expect from entry-level software engineering candidates? 2ï¸âƒ£ How are these expectations reflected in job postings?Here are some key insights: âœ… Hiring managers prioritize non-technical skills such as Adaptability, Proactivity, Dependability, Self-Direction, Passion, Collaboration, Communication, Problem Solving, Courage, Self-Awareness, Self-Confidence, Willingness to Learn, and a Process-Oriented Mindset. âœ… Most of these skills are not explicitly stated in job postings.This means many graduates may feel deterred by technical requirements in postingsâ€”yet hiring managers care deeply about these essential non-technical skills that help candidates grow their technical toolkit over time.A huge thank you to everyone who contributed to our data collection. Your support made this research possible!ğŸ’¬ Iâ€™d love to hear your thoughts: What non-technical skills do you think are most important for entry-level engineers?hashtag#ESEM hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#Hiring hashtag#CareerDevelopment hashtag#Research

Cracking the Data Engineering Interview: My Complete Guide â¬‡ï¸Day by day, demand for Data Engineers is increasing, but many people are still complaining, "Companies are not hiring for the DE role."It's not a hiring issue, but finding skilled employees is very difficult these daysHereâ€™s a roadmap that I believe every aspiring data engineer should follow to confidently crack interviews at top companies â¬‡ï¸I have also shared the complete bootcamp link in the commentğŸ“˜ Step 1: Master the FundamentalsYou need to go beyond tutorials and build a deep understanding in:ğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Python ğŸ: Data structures, functions, file handling, APIsğŸ‘‰ğŸ» SQL: Joins, Window Functions, CTEs, performance tuningğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Data Modeling: Star vs Snowflake schema, OLTP vs OLAP, Slowly Changing DimensionsğŸ“š Pro Tip: Practice with real business scenarios. Don't just SELECT * FROM knowledge.âš™ï¸ Step 2: Tools of the TradeYouâ€™ll be expected to work with:ğŸ‘‰ğŸ» ETL Tools: Airflow, dbt, GlueğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Data Lakes & Warehouses: Snowflake, BigQuery, Redshift, S3ğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Big Data Processing: Apache Spark, Kafka, HadoopCloud Platforms: AWS/GCP/Azure basics (IAM, EC2, S3, etc.)ğŸ’¡ Interviewers love to ask: â€œHow would you build a pipeline if X data came in late or failed?â€ğŸ§  Step 3: Think Like an EngineerMost candidates fail not because they canâ€™t code, but because they canâ€™t design and debug pipelines.Prepare to answer:â€œHow would you design a pipeline to ingest millions of rows daily?â€â€œHow do you ensure data quality and integrity?â€â€œWhat happens if schema changes mid-stream?â€Draw diagrams. âœ¨ Exciting News! âœ¨Iâ€™m thrilled to share that I am officially a first-time author! Our paper, â€œBeyond the Job Posting: What Hiring Managers Seek in Entry-Level Software Engineering Candidatesâ€, co-authored with Bianca Trinkenreich, Ph.D. and Fabio Santos, PhD, has been accepted to the ESEM Conference (Empirical Software Engineering and Measurement)!Our research focused on two main questions: 1ï¸âƒ£ What do hiring managers expect from entry-level software engineering candidates? 2ï¸âƒ£ How are these expectations reflected in job postings?Here are some key insights: âœ… Hiring managers prioritize non-technical skills such as Adaptability, Proactivity, Dependability, Self-Direction, Passion, Collaboration, Communication, Problem Solving, Courage, Self-Awareness, Self-Confidence, Willingness to Learn, and a Process-Oriented Mindset. âœ… Most of these skills are not explicitly stated in job postings.This means many graduates may feel deterred by technical requirements in postingsâ€”yet hiring managers care deeply about these essential non-technical skills that help candidates grow their technical toolkit over time.A huge thank you to everyone who contributed to our data collection. Your support made this research possible!ğŸ’¬ Iâ€™d love to hear your thoughts: What non-technical skills do you think are most important for entry-level engineers?hashtag#ESEM hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#Hiring hashtag#CareerDevelopment hashtag#Research

Cracking the Data Engineering Interview: My Complete Guide â¬‡ï¸Day by day, demand for Data Engineers is increasing, but many people are still complaining, "Companies are not hiring for the DE role."It's not a hiring issue, but finding skilled employees is very difficult these daysHereâ€™s a roadmap that I believe every aspiring data engineer should follow to confidently crack interviews at top companies â¬‡ï¸I have also shared the complete bootcamp link in the commentğŸ“˜ Step 1: Master the FundamentalsYou need to go beyond tutorials and build a deep understanding in:ğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Python ğŸ: Data structures, functions, file handling, APIsğŸ‘‰ğŸ» SQL: Joins, Window Functions, CTEs, performance tuningğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Data Modeling: Star vs Snowflake schema, OLTP vs OLAP, Slowly Changing DimensionsğŸ“š Pro Tip: Practice with real business scenarios. âœ¨ Exciting News! âœ¨Iâ€™m thrilled to share that I am officially a first-time author! Our paper, â€œBeyond the Job Posting: What Hiring Managers Seek in Entry-Level Software Engineering Candidatesâ€, co-authored with Bianca Trinkenreich, Ph.D. and Fabio Santos, PhD, has been accepted to the ESEM Conference (Empirical Software Engineering and Measurement)!Our research focused on two main questions: 1ï¸âƒ£ What do hiring managers expect from entry-level software engineering candidates? 2ï¸âƒ£ How are these expectations reflected in job postings?Here are some key insights: âœ… Hiring managers prioritize non-technical skills such as Adaptability, Proactivity, Dependability, Self-Direction, Passion, Collaboration, Communication, Problem Solving, Courage, Self-Awareness, Self-Confidence, Willingness to Learn, and a Process-Oriented Mindset. âœ… Most of these skills are not explicitly stated in job postings.This means many graduates may feel deterred by technical requirements in postingsâ€”yet hiring managers care deeply about these essential non-technical skills that help candidates grow their technical toolkit over time.A huge thank you to everyone who contributed to our data collection. Your support made this research possible!ğŸ’¬ Iâ€™d love to hear your thoughts: What non-technical skills do you think are most important for entry-level engineers?hashtag#ESEM hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#Hiring hashtag#CareerDevelopment hashtag#Research

âœ¨ Exciting News! âœ¨Iâ€™m thrilled to share that I am officially a first-time author! Our paper, â€œBeyond the Job Posting: What Hiring Managers Seek in Entry-Level Software Engineering Candidatesâ€, co-authored with Bianca Trinkenreich, Ph.D. and Fabio Santos, PhD, has been accepted to the ESEM Conference (Empirical Software Engineering and Measurement)!Our research focused on two main questions: 1ï¸âƒ£ What do hiring managers expect from entry-level software engineering candidates? 2ï¸âƒ£ How are these expectations reflected in job postings?Here are some key insights: âœ… Hiring managers prioritize non-technical skills such as Adaptability, Proactivity, Dependability, Self-Direction, Passion, Collaboration, Communication, Problem Solving, Courage, Self-Awareness, Self-Confidence, Willingness to Learn, and a Process-Oriented Mindset. âœ… Most of these skills are not explicitly stated in job postings.This means many graduates may feel deterred by technical requirements in postingsâ€”yet hiring managers care deeply about these essential non-technical skills that help candidates grow their technical toolkit over time.A huge thank you to everyone who contributed to our data collection. Your support made this research possible!ğŸ’¬ Iâ€™d love to hear your thoughts: What non-technical skills do you think are most important for entry-level engineers?hashtag#ESEM hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#Hiring hashtag#CareerDevelopment hashtag#Research

âœ¨ Exciting News! âœ¨Iâ€™m thrilled to share that I am officially a first-time author! Our paper, â€œBeyond the Job Posting: What Hiring Managers Seek in Entry-Level Software Engineering Candidatesâ€, co-authored with Bianca Trinkenreich, Ph.D. and Fabio Santos, PhD, has been accepted to the ESEM Conference (Empirical Software Engineering and Measurement)!Our research focused on two main questions: 1ï¸âƒ£ What do hiring managers expect from entry-level software engineering candidates? 2ï¸âƒ£ How are these expectations reflected in job postings?Here are some key insights: âœ… Hiring managers prioritize non-technical skills such as Adaptability, Proactivity, Dependability, Self-Direction, Passion, Collaboration, Communication, Problem Solving, Courage, Self-Awareness, Self-Confidence, Willingness to Learn, and a Process-Oriented Mindset. âœ… Most of these skills are not explicitly stated in job postings.This means many graduates may feel deterred by technical requirements in postingsâ€”yet hiring managers care deeply about these essential non-technical skills that help candidates grow their technical toolkit over time.A huge thank you to everyone who contributed to our data collection. Your support made this research possible!ğŸ’¬ Iâ€™d love to hear your thoughts: What non-technical skills do you think are most important for entry-level engineers?hashtag#ESEM hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#Hiring hashtag#CareerDevelopment hashtag#Research

âœ¨ Exciting News! âœ¨Iâ€™m thrilled to share that I am officially a first-time author! Our paper, â€œBeyond the Job Posting: What Hiring Managers Seek in Entry-Level Software Engineering Candidatesâ€, co-authored with Bianca Trinkenreich, Ph.D. and Fabio Santos, PhD, has been accepted to the ESEM Conference (Empirical Software Engineering and Measurement)!Our research focused on two main questions: 1ï¸âƒ£ What do hiring managers expect from entry-level software engineering candidates? 2ï¸âƒ£ How are these expectations reflected in job postings?Here are some key insights: âœ… Hiring managers prioritize non-technical skills such as Adaptability, Proactivity, Dependability, Self-Direction, Passion, Collaboration, Communication, Problem Solving, Courage, Self-Awareness, Self-Confidence, Willingness to Learn, and a Process-Oriented Mindset. âœ… Most of these skills are not explicitly stated in job postings.This means many graduates may feel deterred by technical requirements in postingsâ€”yet hiring managers care deeply about these essential non-technical skills that help candidates grow their technical toolkit over time.A huge thank you to everyone who contributed to our data collection. Your support made this research possible!ğŸ’¬ Iâ€™d love to hear your thoughts: What non-technical skills do you think are most important for entry-level engineers?hashtag#ESEM hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#Hiring hashtag#CareerDevelopment hashtag#Research

AI is birthing roles like prompt engineers and model auditors, accessible to those who adapt fast. This isnâ€™t the endâ€”itâ€™s a pivot point. AI isnâ€™t the enemy; itâ€™s your co-pilot. Upskill in AI tools, chase internships, and think beyond code to domain expertise. The old IT ladder is broken, but the highway to new-age roles is wide open. âœ¨ Exciting News! âœ¨Iâ€™m thrilled to share that I am officially a first-time author! Our paper, â€œBeyond the Job Posting: What Hiring Managers Seek in Entry-Level Software Engineering Candidatesâ€, co-authored with Bianca Trinkenreich, Ph.D. and Fabio Santos, PhD, has been accepted to the ESEM Conference (Empirical Software Engineering and Measurement)!Our research focused on two main questions: 1ï¸âƒ£ What do hiring managers expect from entry-level software engineering candidates? 2ï¸âƒ£ How are these expectations reflected in job postings?Here are some key insights: âœ… Hiring managers prioritize non-technical skills such as Adaptability, Proactivity, Dependability, Self-Direction, Passion, Collaboration, Communication, Problem Solving, Courage, Self-Awareness, Self-Confidence, Willingness to Learn, and a Process-Oriented Mindset. âœ… Most of these skills are not explicitly stated in job postings.This means many graduates may feel deterred by technical requirements in postingsâ€”yet hiring managers care deeply about these essential non-technical skills that help candidates grow their technical toolkit over time.A huge thank you to everyone who contributed to our data collection. Your support made this research possible!ğŸ’¬ Iâ€™d love to hear your thoughts: What non-technical skills do you think are most important for entry-level engineers?hashtag#ESEM hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#Hiring hashtag#CareerDevelopment hashtag#Research

AI is birthing roles like prompt engineers and model auditors, accessible to those who adapt fast. This isnâ€™t the endâ€”itâ€™s a pivot point. AI isnâ€™t the enemy; itâ€™s your co-pilot. âœ¨ Exciting News! âœ¨Iâ€™m thrilled to share that I am officially a first-time author! Our paper, â€œBeyond the Job Posting: What Hiring Managers Seek in Entry-Level Software Engineering Candidatesâ€, co-authored with Bianca Trinkenreich, Ph.D. and Fabio Santos, PhD, has been accepted to the ESEM Conference (Empirical Software Engineering and Measurement)!Our research focused on two main questions: 1ï¸âƒ£ What do hiring managers expect from entry-level software engineering candidates? 2ï¸âƒ£ How are these expectations reflected in job postings?Here are some key insights: âœ… Hiring managers prioritize non-technical skills such as Adaptability, Proactivity, Dependability, Self-Direction, Passion, Collaboration, Communication, Problem Solving, Courage, Self-Awareness, Self-Confidence, Willingness to Learn, and a Process-Oriented Mindset. âœ… Most of these skills are not explicitly stated in job postings.This means many graduates may feel deterred by technical requirements in postingsâ€”yet hiring managers care deeply about these essential non-technical skills that help candidates grow their technical toolkit over time.A huge thank you to everyone who contributed to our data collection. Your support made this research possible!ğŸ’¬ Iâ€™d love to hear your thoughts: What non-technical skills do you think are most important for entry-level engineers?hashtag#ESEM hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#Hiring hashtag#CareerDevelopment hashtag#Research

Meanwhile, Global Capability Centres (GCCs) are hiringâ€”but they want thinkers, not coders, from top-tier institutes. Yet, thereâ€™s hope. AI is birthing roles like prompt engineers and model auditors, accessible to those who adapt fast. This isnâ€™t the endâ€”itâ€™s a pivot point. AI isnâ€™t the enemy; itâ€™s your co-pilot. Upskill in AI tools, chase internships, and think beyond code to domain expertise. The old IT ladder is broken, but the highway to new-age roles is wide open. âœ¨ Exciting News! âœ¨Iâ€™m thrilled to share that I am officially a first-time author! Our paper, â€œBeyond the Job Posting: What Hiring Managers Seek in Entry-Level Software Engineering Candidatesâ€, co-authored with Bianca Trinkenreich, Ph.D. and Fabio Santos, PhD, has been accepted to the ESEM Conference (Empirical Software Engineering and Measurement)!Our research focused on two main questions: 1ï¸âƒ£ What do hiring managers expect from entry-level software engineering candidates? 2ï¸âƒ£ How are these expectations reflected in job postings?Here are some key insights: âœ… Hiring managers prioritize non-technical skills such as Adaptability, Proactivity, Dependability, Self-Direction, Passion, Collaboration, Communication, Problem Solving, Courage, Self-Awareness, Self-Confidence, Willingness to Learn, and a Process-Oriented Mindset. âœ… Most of these skills are not explicitly stated in job postings.This means many graduates may feel deterred by technical requirements in postingsâ€”yet hiring managers care deeply about these essential non-technical skills that help candidates grow their technical toolkit over time.A huge thank you to everyone who contributed to our data collection. Your support made this research possible!ğŸ’¬ Iâ€™d love to hear your thoughts: What non-technical skills do you think are most important for entry-level engineers?hashtag#ESEM hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#Hiring hashtag#CareerDevelopment hashtag#Research

Cracking the Data Engineering Interview: My Complete Guide â¬‡ï¸Day by day, demand for Data Engineers is increasing, but many people are still complaining, "Companies are not hiring for the DE role."It's not a hiring issue, but finding skilled employees is very difficult these daysHereâ€™s a roadmap that I believe every aspiring data engineer should follow to confidently crack interviews at top companies â¬‡ï¸I have also shared the complete bootcamp link in the commentğŸ“˜ Step 1: Master the FundamentalsYou need to go beyond tutorials and build a deep understanding in:ğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Python ğŸ: Data structures, functions, file handling, APIsğŸ‘‰ğŸ» SQL: Joins, Window Functions, CTEs, performance tuningğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Data Modeling: Star vs Snowflake schema, OLTP vs OLAP, Slowly Changing DimensionsğŸ“š Pro Tip: Practice with real business scenarios. Don't just SELECT * FROM knowledge.âš™ï¸ Step 2: Tools of the TradeYouâ€™ll be expected to work with:ğŸ‘‰ğŸ» ETL Tools: Airflow, dbt, GlueğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Data Lakes & Warehouses: Snowflake, BigQuery, Redshift, S3ğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Big Data Processing: Apache Spark, Kafka, HadoopCloud Platforms: AWS/GCP/Azure basics (IAM, EC2, S3, etc.)ğŸ’¡ Interviewers love to ask: â€œHow would you build a pipeline if X data came in late or failed?â€ğŸ§  Step 3: Think Like an EngineerMost candidates fail not because they canâ€™t code, but because they canâ€™t design and debug pipelines.Prepare to answer:â€œHow would you design a pipeline to ingest millions of rows daily?â€â€œHow do you ensure data quality and integrity?â€â€œWhat happens if schema changes mid-stream?â€Draw diagrams. Break down the problem. Think out loud.ğŸ“Š Step 4: Projects > CertificatesReal-world projects >>> random certs.âœ… Build an end-to-end pipeline:- Ingest data from an API- Transform it using Spark/dbt- Store it in a warehouse- Visualize it with Looker or Power BIThis shows not only your skills but also your ability to ship production-ready data systems.ğŸ” Step 5: Mock Interviews & Feedback LoopsDon't prepare in isolation.ğŸ“ˆ Do peer mock interviewsğŸ› ï¸ Use platforms like DataVidhya Code+ to practice PySpark, SQL, Python, DBT, and build Data ModelsğŸ’¬ Ask for resume and project feedback from industry professionals.What if I tell you, everything I mentioned above, you can get it at just one placeâŒ No more jumping from resource to resource, learn everything in one place!Interested? AI is birthing roles like prompt engineers and model auditors, accessible to those who adapt fast. This isnâ€™t the endâ€”itâ€™s a pivot point. AI isnâ€™t the enemy; itâ€™s your co-pilot. Upskill in AI tools, chase internships, and think beyond code to domain expertise. The old IT ladder is broken, but the highway to new-age roles is wide open. âœ¨ Exciting News! âœ¨Iâ€™m thrilled to share that I am officially a first-time author! Our paper, â€œBeyond the Job Posting: What Hiring Managers Seek in Entry-Level Software Engineering Candidatesâ€, co-authored with Bianca Trinkenreich, Ph.D. and Fabio Santos, PhD, has been accepted to the ESEM Conference (Empirical Software Engineering and Measurement)!Our research focused on two main questions: 1ï¸âƒ£ What do hiring managers expect from entry-level software engineering candidates? 2ï¸âƒ£ How are these expectations reflected in job postings?Here are some key insights: âœ… Hiring managers prioritize non-technical skills such as Adaptability, Proactivity, Dependability, Self-Direction, Passion, Collaboration, Communication, Problem Solving, Courage, Self-Awareness, Self-Confidence, Willingness to Learn, and a Process-Oriented Mindset. âœ… Most of these skills are not explicitly stated in job postings.This means many graduates may feel deterred by technical requirements in postingsâ€”yet hiring managers care deeply about these essential non-technical skills that help candidates grow their technical toolkit over time.A huge thank you to everyone who contributed to our data collection. Your support made this research possible!ğŸ’¬ Iâ€™d love to hear your thoughts: What non-technical skills do you think are most important for entry-level engineers?hashtag#ESEM hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#Hiring hashtag#CareerDevelopment hashtag#Research

Don't just SELECT * FROM knowledge.âš™ï¸ Step 2: Tools of the TradeYouâ€™ll be expected to work with:ğŸ‘‰ğŸ» ETL Tools: Airflow, dbt, GlueğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Data Lakes & Warehouses: Snowflake, BigQuery, Redshift, S3ğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Big Data Processing: Apache Spark, Kafka, HadoopCloud Platforms: AWS/GCP/Azure basics (IAM, EC2, S3, etc.)ğŸ’¡ Interviewers love to ask: â€œHow would you build a pipeline if X data came in late or failed?â€ğŸ§  Step 3: Think Like an EngineerMost candidates fail not because they canâ€™t code, but because they canâ€™t design and debug pipelines.Prepare to answer:â€œHow would you design a pipeline to ingest millions of rows daily?â€â€œHow do you ensure data quality and integrity?â€â€œWhat happens if schema changes mid-stream?â€Draw diagrams. âœ¨ Exciting News! âœ¨Iâ€™m thrilled to share that I am officially a first-time author! Our paper, â€œBeyond the Job Posting: What Hiring Managers Seek in Entry-Level Software Engineering Candidatesâ€, co-authored with Bianca Trinkenreich, Ph.D. and Fabio Santos, PhD, has been accepted to the ESEM Conference (Empirical Software Engineering and Measurement)!Our research focused on two main questions: 1ï¸âƒ£ What do hiring managers expect from entry-level software engineering candidates? 2ï¸âƒ£ How are these expectations reflected in job postings?Here are some key insights: âœ… Hiring managers prioritize non-technical skills such as Adaptability, Proactivity, Dependability, Self-Direction, Passion, Collaboration, Communication, Problem Solving, Courage, Self-Awareness, Self-Confidence, Willingness to Learn, and a Process-Oriented Mindset. âœ… Most of these skills are not explicitly stated in job postings.This means many graduates may feel deterred by technical requirements in postingsâ€”yet hiring managers care deeply about these essential non-technical skills that help candidates grow their technical toolkit over time.A huge thank you to everyone who contributed to our data collection. Your support made this research possible!ğŸ’¬ Iâ€™d love to hear your thoughts: What non-technical skills do you think are most important for entry-level engineers?hashtag#ESEM hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#Hiring hashtag#CareerDevelopment hashtag#Research

Cracking the Data Engineering Interview: My Complete Guide â¬‡ï¸Day by day, demand for Data Engineers is increasing, but many people are still complaining, "Companies are not hiring for the DE role."It's not a hiring issue, but finding skilled employees is very difficult these daysHereâ€™s a roadmap that I believe every aspiring data engineer should follow to confidently crack interviews at top companies â¬‡ï¸I have also shared the complete bootcamp link in the commentğŸ“˜ Step 1: Master the FundamentalsYou need to go beyond tutorials and build a deep understanding in:ğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Python ğŸ: Data structures, functions, file handling, APIsğŸ‘‰ğŸ» SQL: Joins, Window Functions, CTEs, performance tuningğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Data Modeling: Star vs Snowflake schema, OLTP vs OLAP, Slowly Changing DimensionsğŸ“š Pro Tip: Practice with real business scenarios. Don't just SELECT * FROM knowledge.âš™ï¸ Step 2: Tools of the TradeYouâ€™ll be expected to work with:ğŸ‘‰ğŸ» ETL Tools: Airflow, dbt, GlueğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Data Lakes & Warehouses: Snowflake, BigQuery, Redshift, S3ğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Big Data Processing: Apache Spark, Kafka, HadoopCloud Platforms: AWS/GCP/Azure basics (IAM, EC2, S3, etc.)ğŸ’¡ Interviewers love to ask: â€œHow would you build a pipeline if X data came in late or failed?â€ğŸ§  Step 3: Think Like an EngineerMost candidates fail not because they canâ€™t code, but because they canâ€™t design and debug pipelines.Prepare to answer:â€œHow would you design a pipeline to ingest millions of rows daily?â€â€œHow do you ensure data quality and integrity?â€â€œWhat happens if schema changes mid-stream?â€Draw diagrams. Break down the problem. âœ¨ Exciting News! âœ¨Iâ€™m thrilled to share that I am officially a first-time author! Our paper, â€œBeyond the Job Posting: What Hiring Managers Seek in Entry-Level Software Engineering Candidatesâ€, co-authored with Bianca Trinkenreich, Ph.D. and Fabio Santos, PhD, has been accepted to the ESEM Conference (Empirical Software Engineering and Measurement)!Our research focused on two main questions: 1ï¸âƒ£ What do hiring managers expect from entry-level software engineering candidates? 2ï¸âƒ£ How are these expectations reflected in job postings?Here are some key insights: âœ… Hiring managers prioritize non-technical skills such as Adaptability, Proactivity, Dependability, Self-Direction, Passion, Collaboration, Communication, Problem Solving, Courage, Self-Awareness, Self-Confidence, Willingness to Learn, and a Process-Oriented Mindset. âœ… Most of these skills are not explicitly stated in job postings.This means many graduates may feel deterred by technical requirements in postingsâ€”yet hiring managers care deeply about these essential non-technical skills that help candidates grow their technical toolkit over time.A huge thank you to everyone who contributed to our data collection. Your support made this research possible!ğŸ’¬ Iâ€™d love to hear your thoughts: What non-technical skills do you think are most important for entry-level engineers?hashtag#ESEM hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#Hiring hashtag#CareerDevelopment hashtag#Research

Cracking the Data Engineering Interview: My Complete Guide â¬‡ï¸Day by day, demand for Data Engineers is increasing, but many people are still complaining, "Companies are not hiring for the DE role."It's not a hiring issue, but finding skilled employees is very difficult these daysHereâ€™s a roadmap that I believe every aspiring data engineer should follow to confidently crack interviews at top companies â¬‡ï¸I have also shared the complete bootcamp link in the commentğŸ“˜ Step 1: Master the FundamentalsYou need to go beyond tutorials and build a deep understanding in:ğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Python ğŸ: Data structures, functions, file handling, APIsğŸ‘‰ğŸ» SQL: Joins, Window Functions, CTEs, performance tuningğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Data Modeling: Star vs Snowflake schema, OLTP vs OLAP, Slowly Changing DimensionsğŸ“š Pro Tip: Practice with real business scenarios. Don't just SELECT * FROM knowledge.âš™ï¸ Step 2: Tools of the TradeYouâ€™ll be expected to work with:ğŸ‘‰ğŸ» ETL Tools: Airflow, dbt, GlueğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Data Lakes & Warehouses: Snowflake, BigQuery, Redshift, S3ğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Big Data Processing: Apache Spark, Kafka, HadoopCloud Platforms: AWS/GCP/Azure basics (IAM, EC2, S3, etc.)ğŸ’¡ Interviewers love to ask: â€œHow would you build a pipeline if X data came in late or failed?â€ğŸ§  Step 3: Think Like an EngineerMost candidates fail not because they canâ€™t code, but because they canâ€™t design and debug pipelines.Prepare to answer:â€œHow would you design a pipeline to ingest millions of rows daily?â€â€œHow do you ensure data quality and integrity?â€â€œWhat happens if schema changes mid-stream?â€Draw diagrams. Break down the problem. Think out loud.ğŸ“Š Step 4: Projects > CertificatesReal-world projects >>> random certs.âœ… Build an end-to-end pipeline:- Ingest data from an API- Transform it using Spark/dbt- Store it in a warehouse- Visualize it with Looker or Power BIThis shows not only your skills but also your ability to ship production-ready data systems.ğŸ” Step 5: Mock Interviews & Feedback LoopsDon't prepare in isolation.ğŸ“ˆ Do peer mock interviewsğŸ› ï¸ Use platforms like DataVidhya Code+ to practice PySpark, SQL, Python, DBT, and build Data ModelsğŸ’¬ Ask for resume and project feedback from industry professionals.What if I tell you, everything I mentioned above, you can get it at just one placeâŒ No more jumping from resource to resource, learn everything in one place!Interested? AI is birthing roles like prompt engineers and model auditors, accessible to those who adapt fast. This isnâ€™t the endâ€”itâ€™s a pivot point. AI isnâ€™t the enemy; itâ€™s your co-pilot. Upskill in AI tools, chase internships, and think beyond code to domain expertise. The old IT ladder is broken, but the highway to new-age roles is wide open. âœ¨ Exciting News! âœ¨Iâ€™m thrilled to share that I am officially a first-time author! Our paper, â€œBeyond the Job Posting: What Hiring Managers Seek in Entry-Level Software Engineering Candidatesâ€, co-authored with Bianca Trinkenreich, Ph.D. and Fabio Santos, PhD, has been accepted to the ESEM Conference (Empirical Software Engineering and Measurement)!Our research focused on two main questions: 1ï¸âƒ£ What do hiring managers expect from entry-level software engineering candidates? 2ï¸âƒ£ How are these expectations reflected in job postings?Here are some key insights: âœ… Hiring managers prioritize non-technical skills such as Adaptability, Proactivity, Dependability, Self-Direction, Passion, Collaboration, Communication, Problem Solving, Courage, Self-Awareness, Self-Confidence, Willingness to Learn, and a Process-Oriented Mindset. âœ… Most of these skills are not explicitly stated in job postings.This means many graduates may feel deterred by technical requirements in postingsâ€”yet hiring managers care deeply about these essential non-technical skills that help candidates grow their technical toolkit over time.A huge thank you to everyone who contributed to our data collection. Your support made this research possible!ğŸ’¬ Iâ€™d love to hear your thoughts: What non-technical skills do you think are most important for entry-level engineers?hashtag#ESEM hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#Hiring hashtag#CareerDevelopment hashtag#Research

Cracking the Data Engineering Interview: My Complete Guide â¬‡ï¸Day by day, demand for Data Engineers is increasing, but many people are still complaining, "Companies are not hiring for the DE role."It's not a hiring issue, but finding skilled employees is very difficult these daysHereâ€™s a roadmap that I believe every aspiring data engineer should follow to confidently crack interviews at top companies â¬‡ï¸I have also shared the complete bootcamp link in the commentğŸ“˜ Step 1: Master the FundamentalsYou need to go beyond tutorials and build a deep understanding in:ğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Python ğŸ: Data structures, functions, file handling, APIsğŸ‘‰ğŸ» SQL: Joins, Window Functions, CTEs, performance tuningğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Data Modeling: Star vs Snowflake schema, OLTP vs OLAP, Slowly Changing DimensionsğŸ“š Pro Tip: Practice with real business scenarios. Don't just SELECT * FROM knowledge.âš™ï¸ Step 2: Tools of the TradeYouâ€™ll be expected to work with:ğŸ‘‰ğŸ» ETL Tools: Airflow, dbt, GlueğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Data Lakes & Warehouses: Snowflake, BigQuery, Redshift, S3ğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Big Data Processing: Apache Spark, Kafka, HadoopCloud Platforms: AWS/GCP/Azure basics (IAM, EC2, S3, etc.)ğŸ’¡ Interviewers love to ask: â€œHow would you build a pipeline if X data came in late or failed?â€ğŸ§  Step 3: Think Like an EngineerMost candidates fail not because they canâ€™t code, but because they canâ€™t design and debug pipelines.Prepare to answer:â€œHow would you design a pipeline to ingest millions of rows daily?â€â€œHow do you ensure data quality and integrity?â€â€œWhat happens if schema changes mid-stream?â€Draw diagrams. Break down the problem. Think out loud.ğŸ“Š Step 4: Projects > CertificatesReal-world projects >>> random certs.âœ… Build an end-to-end pipeline:- Ingest data from an API- Transform it using Spark/dbt- Store it in a warehouse- Visualize it with Looker or Power BIThis shows not only your skills but also your ability to ship production-ready data systems.ğŸ” Step 5: Mock Interviews & Feedback LoopsDon't prepare in isolation.ğŸ“ˆ Do peer mock interviewsğŸ› ï¸ Use platforms like DataVidhya Code+ to practice PySpark, SQL, Python, DBT, and build Data ModelsğŸ’¬ Ask for resume and project feedback from industry professionals.What if I tell you, everything I mentioned above, you can get it at just one placeâŒ No more jumping from resource to resource, learn everything in one place!Interested? Meanwhile, Global Capability Centres (GCCs) are hiringâ€”but they want thinkers, not coders, from top-tier institutes. Yet, thereâ€™s hope. AI is birthing roles like prompt engineers and model auditors, accessible to those who adapt fast. This isnâ€™t the endâ€”itâ€™s a pivot point. AI isnâ€™t the enemy; itâ€™s your co-pilot. Upskill in AI tools, chase internships, and think beyond code to domain expertise. The old IT ladder is broken, but the highway to new-age roles is wide open. âœ¨ Exciting News! âœ¨Iâ€™m thrilled to share that I am officially a first-time author! Our paper, â€œBeyond the Job Posting: What Hiring Managers Seek in Entry-Level Software Engineering Candidatesâ€, co-authored with Bianca Trinkenreich, Ph.D. and Fabio Santos, PhD, has been accepted to the ESEM Conference (Empirical Software Engineering and Measurement)!Our research focused on two main questions: 1ï¸âƒ£ What do hiring managers expect from entry-level software engineering candidates? 2ï¸âƒ£ How are these expectations reflected in job postings?Here are some key insights: âœ… Hiring managers prioritize non-technical skills such as Adaptability, Proactivity, Dependability, Self-Direction, Passion, Collaboration, Communication, Problem Solving, Courage, Self-Awareness, Self-Confidence, Willingness to Learn, and a Process-Oriented Mindset. âœ… Most of these skills are not explicitly stated in job postings.This means many graduates may feel deterred by technical requirements in postingsâ€”yet hiring managers care deeply about these essential non-technical skills that help candidates grow their technical toolkit over time.A huge thank you to everyone who contributed to our data collection. Your support made this research possible!ğŸ’¬ Iâ€™d love to hear your thoughts: What non-technical skills do you think are most important for entry-level engineers?hashtag#ESEM hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#Hiring hashtag#CareerDevelopment hashtag#Research

âœ¨ Exciting News! âœ¨Iâ€™m thrilled to share that I am officially a first-time author! Our paper, â€œBeyond the Job Posting: What Hiring Managers Seek in Entry-Level Software Engineering Candidatesâ€, co-authored with Bianca Trinkenreich, Ph.D. and Fabio Santos, PhD, has been accepted to the ESEM Conference (Empirical Software Engineering and Measurement)!Our research focused on two main questions: 1ï¸âƒ£ What do hiring managers expect from entry-level software engineering candidates? 2ï¸âƒ£ How are these expectations reflected in job postings?Here are some key insights: âœ… Hiring managers prioritize non-technical skills such as Adaptability, Proactivity, Dependability, Self-Direction, Passion, Collaboration, Communication, Problem Solving, Courage, Self-Awareness, Self-Confidence, Willingness to Learn, and a Process-Oriented Mindset. âœ… Most of these skills are not explicitly stated in job postings.This means many graduates may feel deterred by technical requirements in postingsâ€”yet hiring managers care deeply about these essential non-technical skills that help candidates grow their technical toolkit over time.A huge thank you to everyone who contributed to our data collection. Your support made this research possible!ğŸ’¬ Iâ€™d love to hear your thoughts: What non-technical skills do you think are most important for entry-level engineers?hashtag#ESEM hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#Hiring hashtag#CareerDevelopment hashtag#Research

âœ¨ Exciting News! âœ¨Iâ€™m thrilled to share that I am officially a first-time author! Our paper, â€œBeyond the Job Posting: What Hiring Managers Seek in Entry-Level Software Engineering Candidatesâ€, co-authored with Bianca Trinkenreich, Ph.D. and Fabio Santos, PhD, has been accepted to the ESEM Conference (Empirical Software Engineering and Measurement)!Our research focused on two main questions: 1ï¸âƒ£ What do hiring managers expect from entry-level software engineering candidates? 2ï¸âƒ£ How are these expectations reflected in job postings?Here are some key insights: âœ… Hiring managers prioritize non-technical skills such as Adaptability, Proactivity, Dependability, Self-Direction, Passion, Collaboration, Communication, Problem Solving, Courage, Self-Awareness, Self-Confidence, Willingness to Learn, and a Process-Oriented Mindset. âœ… Most of these skills are not explicitly stated in job postings.This means many graduates may feel deterred by technical requirements in postingsâ€”yet hiring managers care deeply about these essential non-technical skills that help candidates grow their technical toolkit over time.A huge thank you to everyone who contributed to our data collection. Your support made this research possible!ğŸ’¬ Iâ€™d love to hear your thoughts: What non-technical skills do you think are most important for entry-level engineers?hashtag#ESEM hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#Hiring hashtag#CareerDevelopment hashtag#Research

âœ¨ Exciting News! âœ¨Iâ€™m thrilled to share that I am officially a first-time author! Our paper, â€œBeyond the Job Posting: What Hiring Managers Seek in Entry-Level Software Engineering Candidatesâ€, co-authored with Bianca Trinkenreich, Ph.D. and Fabio Santos, PhD, has been accepted to the ESEM Conference (Empirical Software Engineering and Measurement)!Our research focused on two main questions: 1ï¸âƒ£ What do hiring managers expect from entry-level software engineering candidates? 2ï¸âƒ£ How are these expectations reflected in job postings?Here are some key insights: âœ… Hiring managers prioritize non-technical skills such as Adaptability, Proactivity, Dependability, Self-Direction, Passion, Collaboration, Communication, Problem Solving, Courage, Self-Awareness, Self-Confidence, Willingness to Learn, and a Process-Oriented Mindset. âœ… Most of these skills are not explicitly stated in job postings.This means many graduates may feel deterred by technical requirements in postingsâ€”yet hiring managers care deeply about these essential non-technical skills that help candidates grow their technical toolkit over time.A huge thank you to everyone who contributed to our data collection. Your support made this research possible!ğŸ’¬ Iâ€™d love to hear your thoughts: What non-technical skills do you think are most important for entry-level engineers?hashtag#ESEM hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#Hiring hashtag#CareerDevelopment hashtag#Research

âœ¨ Exciting News! âœ¨Iâ€™m thrilled to share that I am officially a first-time author! Our paper, â€œBeyond the Job Posting: What Hiring Managers Seek in Entry-Level Software Engineering Candidatesâ€, co-authored with Bianca Trinkenreich, Ph.D. and Fabio Santos, PhD, has been accepted to the ESEM Conference (Empirical Software Engineering and Measurement)!Our research focused on two main questions: 1ï¸âƒ£ What do hiring managers expect from entry-level software engineering candidates? 2ï¸âƒ£ How are these expectations reflected in job postings?Here are some key insights: âœ… Hiring managers prioritize non-technical skills such as Adaptability, Proactivity, Dependability, Self-Direction, Passion, Collaboration, Communication, Problem Solving, Courage, Self-Awareness, Self-Confidence, Willingness to Learn, and a Process-Oriented Mindset. âœ… Most of these skills are not explicitly stated in job postings.This means many graduates may feel deterred by technical requirements in postingsâ€”yet hiring managers care deeply about these essential non-technical skills that help candidates grow their technical toolkit over time.A huge thank you to everyone who contributed to our data collection. Your support made this research possible!ğŸ’¬ Iâ€™d love to hear your thoughts: What non-technical skills do you think are most important for entry-level engineers?hashtag#ESEM hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#Hiring hashtag#CareerDevelopment hashtag#Research

âœ¨ Exciting News! âœ¨Iâ€™m thrilled to share that I am officially a first-time author! Our paper, â€œBeyond the Job Posting: What Hiring Managers Seek in Entry-Level Software Engineering Candidatesâ€, co-authored with Bianca Trinkenreich, Ph.D. and Fabio Santos, PhD, has been accepted to the ESEM Conference (Empirical Software Engineering and Measurement)!Our research focused on two main questions: 1ï¸âƒ£ What do hiring managers expect from entry-level software engineering candidates? 2ï¸âƒ£ How are these expectations reflected in job postings?Here are some key insights: âœ… Hiring managers prioritize non-technical skills such as Adaptability, Proactivity, Dependability, Self-Direction, Passion, Collaboration, Communication, Problem Solving, Courage, Self-Awareness, Self-Confidence, Willingness to Learn, and a Process-Oriented Mindset. âœ… Most of these skills are not explicitly stated in job postings.This means many graduates may feel deterred by technical requirements in postingsâ€”yet hiring managers care deeply about these essential non-technical skills that help candidates grow their technical toolkit over time.A huge thank you to everyone who contributed to our data collection. Your support made this research possible!ğŸ’¬ Iâ€™d love to hear your thoughts: What non-technical skills do you think are most important for entry-level engineers?hashtag#ESEM hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#Hiring hashtag#CareerDevelopment hashtag#Research
